text:
I was super scared.  
“What were you scared of?”  
“That I’d get blamed.”  
“How could you be scared if you felt innocent?”  
Believe it or not, Zossimov asked me exactly that! I know for sure because it was repeated to me word for word. What do you think about that?  

“Well, there’s the evidence.”  
“I’m not talking about evidence right now; I’m talking about how they see themselves. They squeezed him for info until he confessed: ‘I didn’t find it in the street; I found it in the flat where I was painting with Dmitri.’  

“How’d that happen?”  
“Well, Dmitri and I were painting all day, and just as we were about to leave, Dmitri painted my face as a joke. Then he took off running, and I chased him. I was shouting my lungs out! At the bottom of the stairs, I bumped into the porter and some guys—can’t remember how many. The porter yelled at me, and so did the other porter. The porter’s wife came out and joined in, and then a guy with a lady walked in and yelled at us too because Dmitri and I were sprawled across the path.  

I grabbed Dmitri’s hair and knocked him down, and he grabbed mine and started hitting me back. But we were just messing around, not really fighting. Dmitri managed to escape into the street, and I chased him but couldn’t catch him. So, I went back to the flat by myself to clean up my stuff. I was putting things together, waiting for Dmitri to come back, and then I saw something in the corner by the door…

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The conversation reveals a character's fear of being accused despite feeling innocent, highlighting the complexities of guilt and self-perception.
